Negative Constructions All languages have the ability to express . This is usually achieved through the use of:
negative words, such as not or no, which negate a nominal phrase,
negative pronouns, such as noboby or nothing, which express a negative nominal argument by themselves,
negative adverbs, such as never or nowhere,
negative auxiliaries, such as not or the contraction form -n’t, and/or
negative verbal affixes.
We will deal with each one in turn. The final page then deals with any co-occurrence restrictions between the various items when they are used together in full sentences containing a negated object, based upon the type of negation system your language uses.
First, let’s consider the negative meaning ‘not’ or 'no' when it modifies a nominal phrase. Note that not can occur in place of or before the other degree words or wide scope quantifiers, as in the English examples (1-4). Both not and no occur first in the nominal phrase. Negation of a nominal phrase normally occurs either first or last, so that it has the widest of all the modifiers of the noun in the phrase.
not the children.
not all five children.
not just this many children.
not only Sue’s three children.
no little children
no big boys

We also need to consider these negative nominal phrases in complete sentences, beginning with cases where the negated phrase is the subject, such as:
Not all the children came to the party. No more students can enroll in the class.
Take at least one of the nominal phrase examples in the above box(es) and use it as the subject of a full sentence, as in examples (7-8) above.
There are also negative versions of the indefinite pronouns, such as nobody, nothing, none. Note that these are formed from a negative and a generic noun or number. Sometimes these negative indefinites are not merged into a single word, as in no one.
